When Eclipse has been installed into a directory that contains a DBCS 
character, cannot run the default runtime workbench.  In fact, cannot run any 
runtime workbench if it is located in a dir with a DBCS character.

1. Install Eclipse 3.0.1 into directory that contains a double-byte character.
2. Start Eclipse and go to Plug-in Development perspective.
3. Select Run > Run...
4. Select Run-time Workbench and click New.
5. Accept all defaults (pointing to existing Eclipse installation as the 
runtime workbench) and click Run.

Error dialog appears:

"Can not start the configuration.  Detail information is in the log file, do 
you want to open?"


Clicking Yes provides the following error log (this was run on a Simplified 
Chinese installation of Windows 2000 where Eclipse was installed into a

After a little more investigation, it seems that this problem is occurring 
because the config.ini that is written down by PDE contains invalid characters.

For example, if I install Eclipse into a directory with Korean characters 
(testsdk??????), then when I start the IDE and then try to create and run a 
basic Run-time Workbench, I get the error mentioned in this bug's initial 
description.  If I go into the 
eclipse/workspace/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.pde.core/New_configuration/ 
directory in my Eclipse install dir and look in the config.ini file that is 
created there, I see the following:

#Eclipse Runtime Configuration File
osgi.install.area=file:c:/testsdk???/eclipse
osgi.splashPath=file:C:/testsdk???/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.platform_3.0.1/
osgi.configuration.cascaded=false
osgi.framework=file:C:/testsdk???/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.1/
osgi.bundles=reference:file:C:/testsdk???/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.update.con
figurator_3.0.0/@3:start,reference:file:C:/testsdk???/eclipse/plugins/org.eclips
e.core.runtime_3.0.1/@2:start
osgi.bundles.defaultStartLevel=4
eof=eof

So all of the Korean characters have been replaced with '?' characters.  I 
think this may be one of the issues here...

Fixed in the 3.1 stream.

PDE was writing the file manually to control the order in which keys are 
written because the runtime required eof=eof to be the last key written.

This requirement is no more, so PDE now uses Properties.save() to serialize 
the system properties.
This problem is critical to our product, could this be fixed in 3.0.2 as well?
